thread.title: Syracuse football QB AJ Long medically disqualified due to multiple concussions
thread.title_full: Syracuse football QB AJ Long medically disqualified due to multiple concussions | syracuse.com

author: Stephen Bailey | sbailey@syracuse.com
title: Syracuse football QB AJ Long medically disqualified due to multiple concussions
text:
Syracuse, N.Y. â€” Syracuse quarterback AJ Long was medically disqualified on Tuesday due to suffering multiple concussions in college, SU Athletics told Syracuse.com.
Team physician Dr. James Tucker reviewed Long's concussion history and ruled that he cannot participate in football or any other contact sport at Syracuse.
"We appreciate AJ's hard work and the contributions he's made to our program," SU head coach Scott Shafer said. "I look forward to watching him continue to grow both as a student and as a young man. I wish him the best."
The 6-foot, 181-pound sophomore joins defensive end Tyler Marona, offensive tackle Kyle Knapp and defensive lineman Isaiah Johnson as Orange players to be medically disqualified due to concussions in the last two calendar years.
Long, who never had a concussion reported previously, thanked the Orange community in an Instagram post on Monday.
Thank you #CuseNation these past 2-3 years have been incredible!! I'm looking forward to what else happens here in my next 2-3 years!! #s4g #alphalifestyle
A photo posted by Aj Long (@apocalypse4) on Oct 12, 2015 at 10:32am PDT
With starter Terrel Hunt with a fractured fibula for most of last season, Long played in six games as a true freshman, starting five. He completed 54 percent of his passes for 935 yards, four touchdowns and eight interceptions while running for 45 yards and a pair of scores.
Long also dealt with multiple injuries since arriving at SU in January 2014. His throwing hand became numb due to inflammation in his shoulder area following a eight-sack game against North Carolina State.
Early this summer, Long broke a bone in the area of his right hand that required a cast to be put on. He was limited for most of preseason camp and didn't start getting a significant amount of team reps until a couple weeks into the season, coaches said previously.
Long came to Syracuse from Friendship (Lebanon, Tenn.) Christian School as one of two quarterbacks originally in the team's 2014 class. The other, Alin Edouard, never made it to SU due to a "transcript issue."
Long quickly became a fan favorite, helping recruit other players to the Orange, and bringing a competitive approach to his practice and training.
Without him, Syracuse has three healthy quarterbacks on roster: freshman Eric Dungey, sophomore walk-on Zack Mahoney and redshirt sophomore Austin Wilson. Hunt suffered another season-ending injury with a torn Achilles tendon .
The Orange has two quarterbacks pledged to its 2016 class in Rex Culpepper and Lindsey Scott. Culpepper, who is rehabbing a torn ACL , will arrive in January. Scott is the most recent addition to SU's class after pledging on Oct. 5
